pending_diagnosis: DIAGNOSIS: Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP) THE SMOKING GUN: The triad of unremitting, unexplained abdominal pain (often described as "pain out of proportion to exam"), acute ascending neuropathy (mimicking GBS), and rapid-onset psychosis, combined with sustained autonomic hyperactivity (hypertension and tachycardia), points definitively toward a Porphyria crisis. Furthermore, the patient noted having started her menstrual cycle 3 days prior, and she had recently been prescribed an oral contraceptive by her gynecologist (a known precipitating factor). Confirmation was rapid testing showing grossly elevated urine porphobilinogen (PBG) and aminolevulinic acid (ALA). The finding of dark, wine-colored urine after exposure to light (Watson-Schwartz test positive for PBG) provided the definitive bedside clue. PATHOPHYSIOLOGY: AIP is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS), previously known as PBG deaminase. This deficiency impairs the synthesis of Heme. When triggered (by drugs, alcohol, infection, or sex hormones like progesterone/estrogen), the pathway intermediates, specifically ALA and PBG, accumulate to toxic levels. These metabolites are highly neurotoxic, causing damage across the nervous system: 1. Autonomic System: Leads to the classic severe abdominal pain (due to visceral nerve damage), hypertension, and tachycardia. 2. Peripheral System: Causes the rapid, predominantly motor neuropathy (foot drop, bulbar weakness). 3. Central System: Responsible for the seizures, anxiety, and psychosis/hallucinations. Treatment requires prompt cessation of all precipitating factors and administration of high-dose intravenous Heme (Hemin) to repress the synthesis of ALA and PBG, thereby halting the toxic cascade.
